oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sewanee Flag
Flag Used during Founding and Dedication of the University of the South
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: United States flag with thirteen red and white alternating bars, blue field with 13 stars surrounded by a circle of 18, and a gold fringe border. The flag is faded and several sections of fringe are missing.

This presentation flag, which bears the 31 stars of the United States after admission of California in 1851, was carried in the University of the South's initial founding ceremony, which included a patriotic procession on Lookout Mountain on July 4, 1857. It was also used at the dedication marking the University's permanent location on October 10, 1860. Although founded three years earlier by Bishops Leonidas Polk and James Hervey Otey, a permanent location was not obtained until just before the Civil War. The war and its aftermath delayed the start of classes at the University until 1867.
